field_edited_text.value:
THE NEWS..LETTER
Vol. XIV. No. 3.
GALLAUDET EASILY
BEATEN—SCORE 38-3
—0—
Deaf Mutes Prove Easy, and
Half - Scrub Team Rolls up
Comfortable Score — Playing
of Ends Feature of a One-Sided
Game.
Saturday Gallaudet came out to
Homewood and was beaten by the
very comfortably largc margin of
38 to 3. Early in the season St.
John's downed the Mutes 47 to o,
•Ind the dopsters who figure on
comparative scores are busy. Considering that Bridgman and Fulton
were both out of the game, save for
five minutes at the end of the second
half and that Reid and Christhilf
were neither of them on the field at
all the showing compares more than
favorably with that made iby our
Annapolis rivals.
The day certainly reminded one
far more of "the good old summer
time" than it did of the football season and there was many a pound
lost on the field.
The warm weather, the number of
stars that were not in the line up,
the general lack of interest in the
game combined to make it an uninteresting contest. The team played
in a dilly-dally fashion and save for
the good work of Stevenson, Morton and Gillet on the ends it is hard
to pick any very brilliant linemen.
Playing under orders from the
coaches there was a great deal of
punting and the way in which the
ends got down the field under the
kicks was most encouraging. The
tackling generally was the best we
have seen this year.
In the back field Stollenwerck was
Particularly prominent, and his running back kicks was a feature of the
game. Mills was a consistent gainer of ground through the line, while
McCabe, who played half back was
a tower of strength in the defence.
It is a pity that Paulus is not heavier, for if he had a few more pounds
he would make some of the regulars
hustle to hold down their jobs. During the few moments they played
Bridgman and Fulton proved their
already well known ability.
The first half opened with a series
of fumbles that finally placed Gallaudet in a position to kick a goal
from placement their only score.
The rest of the half was a kicking
contest and thanks to ground gained
by Michael's better booting and line
plunges we scored two touchdowns.
—0—
Concluded in column 2.

November 15, 1909.
''HOPKINS NIGHT"
—0—
First "Hopkins Night," November 2o—Crowd Expected.
The first benefit night held by the
"Hullabaloo" board will be at Ford's
Theatre, Saturday, November 20, the
night of the St. John's game. This
is one of the few ways that there are
to raise money for the publishing of
the "Hullabaloo," and it is the duty
of everyone to attend and help th2
cause along.
No more opportune time could have
been chosen than this. The St. John's
game will be over, and everyone will
be feeling flush, in the finest kind of
mood, ready either to applaud the
heroine or hiss the villain. St. John's
will probably occupy a large part of
the theatre, and it is "up to us" to
fill the "better half." This is an occasion when the undergaduates should
come out "en masse ;" Hopkins spirit
should be at its high-water mark;
andl neither breaking of training nor
Bacchanalian feasts should prevent
Apropos
anyone from attending.
here are a few words to the freshmen who have never witnessed a
Hopkins night. They have their golden opportunity once lost never returns; they may be able to see future
Hopkins nights, and probably will before the year is over, but they will
never be able to see one like this
again.
The play, Miss Hattie Williams in
"Detective Sparks,"from all accounts,
is going to be well worth seeing; but
this is immaterial, for the main feature is not so much the play as "Hopkins Night."
A regular feature of the football
games this season is a tumbling act
by Johnny Huck, 'ii, who at every
game played at Homewood gets bowled over by some over-enthusiastic
football player, while standing peaceably by, holding up the Hopkins end
of the lines. This and the cane worn
by our head linesman in a measure
take the place of the boomerang exhibitions that were formerly given by
Dr. Robert Wood.
Dr. Roulston is not the only member of the Faculty who married during the summer, for Dr. Cowles, of
the Biology Department, has done
likewise.
Continued from column I.
—0—
The second half was all Hopkins and
at the end of the twenty minutes the
score was 38 to 3.

Price, 5 cents per copy.

HOPKINS VS. ST. JOHN'S
GREAT GAME THIS WEEK
--o—
Annual Contest this Saturday—
Our Team and Coaches Confident of a Blue Victory—A
Record Crowd to See the Gridiron Battle.

FIRST DEFEAT FROM
DICKINSON—I2 TO 6.
—o—
Hopkins Defeated but Not OutPlayed by Strong Dickinson
Team. Improvement Continues and Our Line Shows up
Stronger than Ever.

Saturday all Baltimore cars will run
"Direct to the Hopkins Athletic
Field," and every Hopkins man, be
he alumnus or undergraduate,to whom
kind Providence has given health and
fifty cents will turn his face toward
Homewood, for Saturday is the day
of all football days. Saturday is the
day that Hopkins men believe will
go down in our football history in
great, big, red, capital letters, for on
next Saturday the St. Johns game is
to be played, and everyone has a
pretty strong "hunch" that our team
is going to square some old scores.
The confidence that the undergraduates place in Captain McCabe's
eleven is far from unfounded. Never
before has there been such a wealth
of material for the coaches to select
from, and if need be we can play
two teams in the game and finish with
practically as strong a combination as
was sent in as the first string. Never
before have we had such a heavy team
that withal is so speedy. Never before have we had a team that showed more true football spirit, or was so
imbued with the never-say-die idea.
Never before have we enjoyed the
advantage of Mr. Gill's coaching,
Never before have we had such alumni backing and such undergraduate
enthusiasm. The team was slow in
developing, but it has rounded into
as perfect a football machine as ever
wore the black and blue. The victory
from Western Maryland showed the
spirit that wins lost games, the fame
against Dickinson demonstrated high
ability to handle an open game, —St.
John's favorite play—and next Saturday will come the climax of a most
successful season.
There is no use to recount the "St.
John's' hoodoo" and to tell how, more
than once, they have beaten a better
team, thanks to better luck. It seems
this year that we can give them all
luck and still take them into camp.
At least so think the coaches, and the
team shares their confidence, while
those "On the Side of the Line" are
certainly expecting to see "their heroes shine."
Our team is fit as a fiddle, and is
going to put up the game of its season next Saturday. A record crowd
of alumni are coming out and every
Continued on page 2.

Saturday week the strong team
from Dickinson, led by the famous
Mount Pleasant, came down from
Pennsylvania and gave Captain McCabe's men their first taste of defeat.
Hopkins hardly dared hope for a victory, but the fact remains that there
was a large element of luck in determining the final score.
As was expected, Mount Pleasant
got off some beautiful kicks, and the
way his ends got down the field under them was a sight worth several
trips to Homewood; but this was the
only feature of the game where Dickinson was markedly superior. We
were led to .expect a game full of
forward passes, on-side kicks, and
tricks, and we were not disappointed.
This is the kind of a game that we
hear St. John's relies upon, and the
effective way in which.. such tactics
were foiled certainly "looked good"
to our rooters. The line from end to
end showed itself to be improving
continually, while the back-field demonstrated anew its ground-gaining
ability.
The shifting of Stevenson to end
seems to have found a most useful position for the ex-Yale player, and he
and Musser are a pair of wings that
can well be relied upon. Of the linemen, Michael won everlasting fame
by his "seventy yard walk," and
throughout played a star game. Stollenwerck ran the team with rare good
judgment and gained plenty of ground
when he carried the ball. Bridgman
was the brightest star of the backs,
though both Mills and Fulton gained
consistently when called upon.
All of the scoring was done in the
first half — Dickinson making two
touchdowns, thanks quite as much to
Hopkins' fumbles as their own good
playing, and "Babe" literally walking seventy yards with a ball he found
somewhere, nobody knows just where.
The second hal was slightly in Hopkins' favor. Fumbles, however, prevented our scoring. Toward the end
of the game Dickinson showed a little disposition to "mess things up,"
.and they certainly took their own
sweet time as the half drew towarn
a close, probably feeling that a victory saved by the final whistle was
better than a tied score.
Continued on page 2.

THE NEWS-LETTER

The News-Letter
r---Vol. XIV. November 15, 1909. No. 3
SUBSCRIPTIONS:
$1.50 per year.
5 cents per copy.
Published weekly during the college
year by the undergraduates of the
Johns Hopkins University.
Business communications should be
addressed to the BUSINESS MANAGER;
all articles and other communications
should be sent to the EDITOR-IN-CHIEF.
Editor-in-Chief:
G. R.. Veazey, '10.
Assistant Editors:
E. D. Martin,
N. W. Haynes, '12.
T. S. Will, '10.
L. Rogers, '12.
Business Manager:
H. P. Makel, 'II.
Assistant Business Manager:
G. P. Thomas, '12.
The Board regrets to announce the
resignation of Mr. Alan C. Woods,
'to, because of pressure of studies.
Mr. Woods has been a member of
the staff for the last two years, and
we trust that, as far as time will permit, he will continue his contributions
to our columns.
We publish in another column a
letter just received from an alumnus,
concerning the welfare of the NewsLena. As to alumni interest in the
paper, it has been pointed out that,
unlike other colleges, Johns Hopkins
maintains no alumni publication, although the project has been several
times seriously considered. In absence of any such publication, and,
also, considering the number which
our in-town alumni have now reached, it is believed that the News-Letter
may at least receive a trial to fill the
deficiency. An alumni circulation of
several hundred among the city, and
even at a distance also, would accomp'ish two things: (1) Those alumni
who are intersted in the University
t:ctivities would be continually posted
every week as to events about to take
place here—an information more reliable than that gained from rumor.
(2) Alumni may always find in the
News-Letter a vehicle for expression of opinion as to questions concerning those University affairs which
from time to time arise for discussion. The alumnus may find
through the News-Letter columns the
audience to which he wishes to appeal.
Considering, then, that the NewsLetter can readily be of service in
these two directions, the Board is this
year attempting to form a large
alumni subscription list. The suggestions and attitude of several members of the Alumni Council have been
so encouraging that it has been
thought reasonable to make the attempt.

The time for the annual University debate is fast approaching, and
if the call for candidates has not already been issued, the trumpet will
surely be heard to sound before long.
The debate committee has been appointed, and arrangements are being
made for the conflict. The University
team will lose several men by graduation, and it is hoped that new candidates will appear from all the
classes at the University. Freshmen
rarely make the University team, but,
just as the "scrubs" in football are of
the greatest service, the freshmen in
debate, too, always form good material for practice for the older candidates. It is to be hoped, then, that
a large crop of debaters will report
when the. call is issued.
To the Editor of the News-Letter,
The Johns Hopkins University:
Alumni of the late nineties will
remember that the News-Letter was
first conducted as an experiment, and
that it did not receive final sanction
from the Trustees until it had proved
itself harmless. Since that time until
the present year the paper has been
a fortnightly periodical, and successive boards of editors have struggled
with the problem of giving it a definite character. It has been a belated
newspaper, a hasty and slender literary magazine, and ineffecti.ye comic
journal; but it has never, I think,
succeeded in being distinctively one
thing or the other. The present board
of editors is to be commended for
its solution of the problem. The NewsLetter as a thorough-going college
newspaper is at least consistent with
its name and dominated by a consistent purpose.
This change in the form and purpose of the paper is so great as to
make it practically a new venture. If
it is to succeed and grow into the
place that exists for it in Hopkins
life, it must be supported, first of
all, by the students. The editors
count upon such support and they will
doubtless receive it. But there are
two other classes whose good opinion
the paper needs and whose approval
the editors may, through a natural
delicacy, hesitate to ask for boldly.
I mean the faculty and the alumni.
In past years some members of the
faculty have frankly and consistently
disapproved of the News-Letter.
Themselves editors of or contributors
to learned journals that carry the
fame of Johns Hopkins abroad, they
winced at the amateurishness of the
student journal and cried out against
the youthful slips in proofreading that
marred its pages. Such persons
should be mollified by the change to
a weekly. A newspaper may be pardoned some marks of haste. A college newspaper may show signs of
unpracticed, or even careless, hands
without disgracing us abroad or at
home.
Other members of the faculty have
paid for the News-Letter and have
never given it a further thought. The
proof-reading didn't trouble them, for

they never saw it; unless some specially egregious blunder was brought
to their notice. Members of the faculty who have been indifferent to the
News-Letter may perhaps find in the
future that as a student transcript of
what is going on and a useful forecast of what is about to come it is
worthy of a passing glance.
The other class, the alumni, have
hitherto taken no interest whatever
in the paper. This is not surprising,
for until a year or two ago the great
majority of the alumni seemed little
interested in anything that their successors in the University were doing.
The notable awakening of the alumni
that has taken place in the last two
years, particularly the formation of
the Alumni Council, changes all this.
The News-Letter stands ready to
serve as organ for the new movement
among Hopkins alumni. Its columns
are open for their announcements; its
editors welcome alumni news. They
deserve and should receive alumni
subscriptions and alumni interest.
J. C. F., '99.

Continued from page I.
—0—
undergraduate who is not tied to
somebody's else sister's boa will be
in the cheering section, lending his
voice to a mighty chorus of "Hullabaloos," "Long Rays," and "Who
Waas." There has been many a game
won by the cheering section and "she"
will not elope from the stand; so let's
all get together and help the team
put the double cross on that hoodoo.
Continued from page I.
The game showed the continued improvement of the Hopkins team. At
times they played brilliant football,
but then again there were decidedly
ragged spots. Could they have played
up to their best form all the time
the score board would have told a
different story. Probably the worst
feature of their game was the fumbling, combined as it was with a most
distressing inability to recover a loose
ball.

THE Y. M. C. .A.

The Bible Class work of the Association is progressing very well.The
graduate students' class, led by Dr.
Steiner, has the largest enrollment.
Following is a list of the classes. If
any undergraduate finds it impossible
to enroll in an undergraduate class,
Dr. Steiner would be pleased to have
him attend the graduate class on Sunday afternoons.
The Graduate Students' Class, led
by Dr. Steiner, meets Sunday afternoons at 3 o'clock. Study: "The
Book of Isaiah."
Junior Class, led by J. M. Holmes,
meets Thursday, at one o'clock.
Study: "Work and Teachings of the
Earlier Prophets."
Sophomore Class, led by H. B. Hering, meets Wednesday at i o'clock.
Subject: "New Studies in Acts."
Freshman Classes,led by J. F. Hunter and J. M. Holmes, meet Thursday, and Tuesday, at i o'clock. Subject: "Studies in the Life of Christ."
The Student Volunteer Convention
will be held this year at Rochester,
New York, December 29 to January
2. The Convention is held every four
years, and delegates are chosen from
all the colleges in the United States
and Canada. The morning and evening sessions are devoted to platform
addresses, and the afternoons to sectional conferences. There will be
present missionary representatives
from every country in the world, and
many speakers of world-wide reputation. The Hopkins Association is allowed three representatives. Besides
the General Secretary and Mr. J. F.
Hunter, W. 0. Weyforth and S. E.
Pickering have been chosen as delegates.. Every student has received
some of the slips which read "An ad
in the Hopkins Handbook pays." This
year the Association will lose about
twenty-five or thirty dollars on the

Handbook, and it would be appreciated if the student would use the
slips when making purchases of our
advertisers. Since we have no dormitories where goods may be sent, the
stores have no means of ascertaining
the amount of Hopkins trade they receive. We have taken this way of
informing them, and hope the students will use the slips. Additional
slips may be obtained from the General Secretary.
We would like to call the attention
of the students to the Chapel servicTs
held every morning, except Saturday
and Sunday, at 8.45. A good way
to start the day is by spending a few
minutes in quiet meditation and
thought. The Chapel service affords
this opportunity, and we hope an increasing number will avail themselves
of it. The leader for this week is
Mr. Rogers E. Galt.

shall be able to accept, owing to a
former understanding with Washington and Lee University.

game. Chip in as much as you can.

SCRUBS—DUNHAMS.
1111 •
The "- Scrubs" defeated the first team
of the Boys'Latin School on Saturday
morning, November 6, at Homewood.
The score was very close, being 6 to
5.
Lawton and Packard played an excellent game for the "Scrubs." Packard hit the line at a good pace several times.
The ease with which Alec Robinson
played was a decided feature of the
game. Alec is an ex-Tome man and
he surely has the art of football
"down pat."
During the first half the "Scrubs"
were playing with the Dunhams boys,
but when a touchdown was made by
the visitors the "Scrubs" woke up all
of a sudden and played a fast game.
If the second half had been just ten
minutes longer the "Scrubs" would
have walked away with Dunhams.
Dunhams failed miserably at goal
several times.
Holliday, Iglehart and Fouke featured for Dunhams.
SCHMEISSER

ELECTED

The Lacrosse Team have finished
their mail balloting for a captain for
the coming season, and Gerhard L.
Schmeisser, '12, has been elected.
Schmeisser played goal on the team
last season, and should make an excellent leader for the team. He is
not only a strong player himself, but
he comes from a family that has lacrosse bred in its very bones. The
Schmeisser brothers hold a place in
Hopkins lacrosse that is comparable
to that held by the Poe family in football at Princeton. Our present lacrosse captain is the third of the family to hold this honorable position.
SOPHOMORE MEETING
The Sophomores held a meeting last
Tuesday and elected Max G. Paulus
the captain of their lacrosse team, and
J. K. Burg-an its manager. Captain
Schmeisser of the 'varsity lacrosse
team spoke and urged every member
of the class who is not out for football or track to come out for the lacrosse team this season.
The class voted to assess each of
its members to pay for the class banner, and T. Brooke Price, John S.
Fulton and G. H.Todes were appointed a committee to select the design
and order the flag.

THE NEWS..LETTER
Vol. XIV. No. 3.
GALLAUDET EASILY
BEATEN—SCORE 38-3
—0—
Deaf Mutes Prove Easy, and
Half - Scrub Team Rolls up
Comfortable Score — Playing
of Ends Feature of a One-Sided
Game.
Saturday Gallaudet came out to
Homewood and was beaten by the
very comfortably largc margin of
38 to 3. Early in the season St.
John's downed the Mutes 47 to o,
•Ind the dopsters who figure on
comparative scores are busy. Considering that Bridgman and Fulton
were both out of the game, save for
five minutes at the end of the second
half and that Reid and Christhilf
were neither of them on the field at
all the showing compares more than
favorably with that made iby our
Annapolis rivals.
The day certainly reminded one
far more of "the good old summer
time" than it did of the football season and there was many a pound
lost on the field.
The warm weather, the number of
stars that were not in the line up,
the general lack of interest in the
game combined to make it an uninteresting contest. The team played
in a dilly-dally fashion and save for
the good work of Stevenson, Morton and Gillet on the ends it is hard
to pick any very brilliant linemen.
Playing under orders from the
coaches there was a great deal of
punting and the way in which the
ends got down the field under the
kicks was most encouraging. The
tackling generally was the best we
have seen this year.
In the back field Stollenwerck was
Particularly prominent, and his running back kicks was a feature of the
game. Mills was a consistent gainer of ground through the line, while
McCabe, who played half back was
a tower of strength in the defence.
It is a pity that Paulus is not heavier, for if he had a few more pounds
he would make some of the regulars
hustle to hold down their jobs. During the few moments they played
Bridgman and Fulton proved their
already well known ability.
The first half opened with a series
of fumbles that finally placed Gallaudet in a position to kick a goal
from placement their only score.
The rest of the half was a kicking
contest and thanks to ground gained
by Michael's better booting and line
plunges we scored two touchdowns.
—0—
Concluded in column 2.

November 15, 1909.
''HOPKINS NIGHT"
—0—
First "Hopkins Night," November 2o—Crowd Expected.
The first benefit night held by the
"Hullabaloo" board will be at Ford's
Theatre, Saturday, November 20, the
night of the St. John's game. This
is one of the few ways that there are
to raise money for the publishing of
the "Hullabaloo," and it is the duty
of everyone to attend and help th2
cause along.
No more opportune time could have
been chosen than this. The St. John's
game will be over, and everyone will
be feeling flush, in the finest kind of
mood, ready either to applaud the
heroine or hiss the villain. St. John's
will probably occupy a large part of
the theatre, and it is "up to us" to
fill the "better half." This is an occasion when the undergaduates should
come out "en masse ;" Hopkins spirit
should be at its high-water mark;
andl neither breaking of training nor
Bacchanalian feasts should prevent
Apropos
anyone from attending.
here are a few words to the freshmen who have never witnessed a
Hopkins night. They have their golden opportunity once lost never returns; they may be able to see future
Hopkins nights, and probably will before the year is over, but they will
never be able to see one like this
again.
The play, Miss Hattie Williams in
"Detective Sparks,"from all accounts,
is going to be well worth seeing; but
this is immaterial, for the main feature is not so much the play as "Hopkins Night."
A regular feature of the football
games this season is a tumbling act
by Johnny Huck, 'ii, who at every
game played at Homewood gets bowled over by some over-enthusiastic
football player, while standing peaceably by, holding up the Hopkins end
of the lines. This and the cane worn
by our head linesman in a measure
take the place of the boomerang exhibitions that were formerly given by
Dr. Robert Wood.
Dr. Roulston is not the only member of the Faculty who married during the summer, for Dr. Cowles, of
the Biology Department, has done
likewise.
Continued from column I.
—0—
The second half was all Hopkins and
at the end of the twenty minutes the
score was 38 to 3.

Price, 5 cents per copy.

HOPKINS VS. ST. JOHN'S
GREAT GAME THIS WEEK
--o—
Annual Contest this Saturday—
Our Team and Coaches Confident of a Blue Victory—A
Record Crowd to See the Gridiron Battle.

FIRST DEFEAT FROM
DICKINSON—I2 TO 6.
—o—
Hopkins Defeated but Not OutPlayed by Strong Dickinson
Team. Improvement Continues and Our Line Shows up
Stronger than Ever.

Saturday all Baltimore cars will run
"Direct to the Hopkins Athletic
Field," and every Hopkins man, be
he alumnus or undergraduate,to whom
kind Providence has given health and
fifty cents will turn his face toward
Homewood, for Saturday is the day
of all football days. Saturday is the
day that Hopkins men believe will
go down in our football history in
great, big, red, capital letters, for on
next Saturday the St. Johns game is
to be played, and everyone has a
pretty strong "hunch" that our team
is going to square some old scores.
The confidence that the undergraduates place in Captain McCabe's
eleven is far from unfounded. Never
before has there been such a wealth
of material for the coaches to select
from, and if need be we can play
two teams in the game and finish with
practically as strong a combination as
was sent in as the first string. Never
before have we had such a heavy team
that withal is so speedy. Never before have we had a team that showed more true football spirit, or was so
imbued with the never-say-die idea.
Never before have we enjoyed the
advantage of Mr. Gill's coaching,
Never before have we had such alumni backing and such undergraduate
enthusiasm. The team was slow in
developing, but it has rounded into
as perfect a football machine as ever
wore the black and blue. The victory
from Western Maryland showed the
spirit that wins lost games, the fame
against Dickinson demonstrated high
ability to handle an open game, —St.
John's favorite play—and next Saturday will come the climax of a most
successful season.
There is no use to recount the "St.
John's' hoodoo" and to tell how, more
than once, they have beaten a better
team, thanks to better luck. It seems
this year that we can give them all
luck and still take them into camp.
At least so think the coaches, and the
team shares their confidence, while
those "On the Side of the Line" are
certainly expecting to see "their heroes shine."
Our team is fit as a fiddle, and is
going to put up the game of its season next Saturday. A record crowd
of alumni are coming out and every
Continued on page 2.

Saturday week the strong team
from Dickinson, led by the famous
Mount Pleasant, came down from
Pennsylvania and gave Captain McCabe's men their first taste of defeat.
Hopkins hardly dared hope for a victory, but the fact remains that there
was a large element of luck in determining the final score.
As was expected, Mount Pleasant
got off some beautiful kicks, and the
way his ends got down the field under them was a sight worth several
trips to Homewood; but this was the
only feature of the game where Dickinson was markedly superior. We
were led to .expect a game full of
forward passes, on-side kicks, and
tricks, and we were not disappointed.
This is the kind of a game that we
hear St. John's relies upon, and the
effective way in which.. such tactics
were foiled certainly "looked good"
to our rooters. The line from end to
end showed itself to be improving
continually, while the back-field demonstrated anew its ground-gaining
ability.
The shifting of Stevenson to end
seems to have found a most useful position for the ex-Yale player, and he
and Musser are a pair of wings that
can well be relied upon. Of the linemen, Michael won everlasting fame
by his "seventy yard walk," and
throughout played a star game. Stollenwerck ran the team with rare good
judgment and gained plenty of ground
when he carried the ball. Bridgman
was the brightest star of the backs,
though both Mills and Fulton gained
consistently when called upon.
All of the scoring was done in the
first half — Dickinson making two
touchdowns, thanks quite as much to
Hopkins' fumbles as their own good
playing, and "Babe" literally walking seventy yards with a ball he found
somewhere, nobody knows just where.
The second hal was slightly in Hopkins' favor. Fumbles, however, prevented our scoring. Toward the end
of the game Dickinson showed a little disposition to "mess things up,"
.and they certainly took their own
sweet time as the half drew towarn
a close, probably feeling that a victory saved by the final whistle was
better than a tied score.
Continued on page 2.

THE NEWS-LETTER

The News-Letter
r---Vol. XIV. November 15, 1909. No. 3
SUBSCRIPTIONS:
$1.50 per year.
5 cents per copy.
Published weekly during the college
year by the undergraduates of the
Johns Hopkins University.
Business communications should be
addressed to the BUSINESS MANAGER;
all articles and other communications
should be sent to the EDITOR-IN-CHIEF.
Editor-in-Chief:
G. R.. Veazey, '10.
Assistant Editors:
E. D. Martin,
N. W. Haynes, '12.
T. S. Will, '10.
L. Rogers, '12.
Business Manager:
H. P. Makel, 'II.
Assistant Business Manager:
G. P. Thomas, '12.
The Board regrets to announce the
resignation of Mr. Alan C. Woods,
'to, because of pressure of studies.
Mr. Woods has been a member of
the staff for the last two years, and
we trust that, as far as time will permit, he will continue his contributions
to our columns.
We publish in another column a
letter just received from an alumnus,
concerning the welfare of the NewsLena. As to alumni interest in the
paper, it has been pointed out that,
unlike other colleges, Johns Hopkins
maintains no alumni publication, although the project has been several
times seriously considered. In absence of any such publication, and,
also, considering the number which
our in-town alumni have now reached, it is believed that the News-Letter
may at least receive a trial to fill the
deficiency. An alumni circulation of
several hundred among the city, and
even at a distance also, would accomp'ish two things: (1) Those alumni
who are intersted in the University
t:ctivities would be continually posted
every week as to events about to take
place here—an information more reliable than that gained from rumor.
(2) Alumni may always find in the
News-Letter a vehicle for expression of opinion as to questions concerning those University affairs which
from time to time arise for discussion. The alumnus may find
through the News-Letter columns the
audience to which he wishes to appeal.
Considering, then, that the NewsLetter can readily be of service in
these two directions, the Board is this
year attempting to form a large
alumni subscription list. The suggestions and attitude of several members of the Alumni Council have been
so encouraging that it has been
thought reasonable to make the attempt.

The time for the annual University debate is fast approaching, and
if the call for candidates has not already been issued, the trumpet will
surely be heard to sound before long.
The debate committee has been appointed, and arrangements are being
made for the conflict. The University
team will lose several men by graduation, and it is hoped that new candidates will appear from all the
classes at the University. Freshmen
rarely make the University team, but,
just as the "scrubs" in football are of
the greatest service, the freshmen in
debate, too, always form good material for practice for the older candidates. It is to be hoped, then, that
a large crop of debaters will report
when the. call is issued.
To the Editor of the News-Letter,
The Johns Hopkins University:
Alumni of the late nineties will
remember that the News-Letter was
first conducted as an experiment, and
that it did not receive final sanction
from the Trustees until it had proved
itself harmless. Since that time until
the present year the paper has been
a fortnightly periodical, and successive boards of editors have struggled
with the problem of giving it a definite character. It has been a belated
newspaper, a hasty and slender literary magazine, and ineffecti.ye comic
journal; but it has never, I think,
succeeded in being distinctively one
thing or the other. The present board
of editors is to be commended for
its solution of the problem. The NewsLetter as a thorough-going college
newspaper is at least consistent with
its name and dominated by a consistent purpose.
This change in the form and purpose of the paper is so great as to
make it practically a new venture. If
it is to succeed and grow into the
place that exists for it in Hopkins
life, it must be supported, first of
all, by the students. The editors
count upon such support and they will
doubtless receive it. But there are
two other classes whose good opinion
the paper needs and whose approval
the editors may, through a natural
delicacy, hesitate to ask for boldly.
I mean the faculty and the alumni.
In past years some members of the
faculty have frankly and consistently
disapproved of the News-Letter.
Themselves editors of or contributors
to learned journals that carry the
fame of Johns Hopkins abroad, they
winced at the amateurishness of the
student journal and cried out against
the youthful slips in proofreading that
marred its pages. Such persons
should be mollified by the change to
a weekly. A newspaper may be pardoned some marks of haste. A college newspaper may show signs of
unpracticed, or even careless, hands
without disgracing us abroad or at
home.
Other members of the faculty have
paid for the News-Letter and have
never given it a further thought. The
proof-reading didn't trouble them, for

they never saw it; unless some specially egregious blunder was brought
to their notice. Members of the faculty who have been indifferent to the
News-Letter may perhaps find in the
future that as a student transcript of
what is going on and a useful forecast of what is about to come it is
worthy of a passing glance.
The other class, the alumni, have
hitherto taken no interest whatever
in the paper. This is not surprising,
for until a year or two ago the great
majority of the alumni seemed little
interested in anything that their successors in the University were doing.
The notable awakening of the alumni
that has taken place in the last two
years, particularly the formation of
the Alumni Council, changes all this.
The News-Letter stands ready to
serve as organ for the new movement
among Hopkins alumni. Its columns
are open for their announcements; its
editors welcome alumni news. They
deserve and should receive alumni
subscriptions and alumni interest.
J. C. F., '99.

Continued from page I.
—0—
undergraduate who is not tied to
somebody's else sister's boa will be
in the cheering section, lending his
voice to a mighty chorus of "Hullabaloos," "Long Rays," and "Who

won by the cheering section and "she"
will not elope from the stand; so let's

Continued from page I.
The game showed the continued improvement of the Hopkins team. At
times they played brilliant football,
but then again there were decidedly
ragged spots. Could they have played
up to their best form all the time
the score board would have told a
different story. Probably the worst
feature of their game was the fumbling, combined as it was with a most
distressing inability to recover a loose
ball.

The Bible Class work of the Association is progressing very well.The
graduate students' class, led by Dr.
Steiner, has the largest enrollment.
Following is a list of the classes. If
any undergraduate finds it impossible
to enroll in an undergraduate class,
Dr. Steiner would be pleased to have
him attend the graduate class on Sunday afternoons.
The Graduate Students' Class, led
by Dr. Steiner, meets Sunday afternoons at 3 o'clock. Study: "The
Book of Isaiah."
Junior Class, led by J. M. Holmes,
meets Thursday, at one o'clock.
Study: "Work and Teachings of the
Earlier Prophets."
Sophomore Class, led by H. B. Hering, meets Wednesday at i o'clock.
Subject: "New Studies in Acts."
Freshman Classes,led by J. F. Hunter and J. M. Holmes, meet Thursday, and Tuesday, at i o'clock. Subject: "Studies in the Life of Christ."
The Student Volunteer Convention
will be held this year at Rochester,
New York, December 29 to January
2. The Convention is held every four
years, and delegates are chosen from
all the colleges in the United States
and Canada. The morning and evening sessions are devoted to platform
addresses, and the afternoons to sectional conferences. There will be
present missionary representatives
from every country in the world, and
many speakers of world-wide reputation. The Hopkins Association is allowed three representatives. Besides
the General Secretary and Mr. J. F.
Hunter, W. 0. Weyforth and S. E.
Pickering have been chosen as delegates.. Every student has received
some of the slips which read "An ad
in the Hopkins Handbook pays." This
year the Association will lose about
twenty-five or thirty dollars on the

Handbook, and it would be appreciated if the student would use the
slips when making purchases of our
advertisers. Since we have no dormitories where goods may be sent, the
stores have no means of ascertaining
the amount of Hopkins trade they receive. We have taken this way of
informing them, and hope the students will use the slips. Additional
slips may be obtained from the General Secretary.
We would like to call the attention
of the students to the Chapel servicTs
held every morning, except Saturday
and Sunday, at 8.45. A good way
to start the day is by spending a few
minutes in quiet meditation and
thought. The Chapel service affords
this opportunity, and we hope an increasing number will avail themselves
of it. The leader for this week is
Mr. Rogers E. Galt.

SCRUBS—DUNHAMS.
1111 •
The "- Scrubs" defeated the first team
of the Boys'Latin School on Saturday
morning, November 6, at Homewood.
The score was very close, being 6 to
5.
Lawton and Packard played an excellent game for the "Scrubs." Packard hit the line at a good pace several times.
The ease with which Alec Robinson
played was a decided feature of the
game. Alec is an ex-Tome man and
he surely has the art of football
"down pat."
During the first half the "Scrubs"
were playing with the Dunhams boys,
but when a touchdown was made by
the visitors the "Scrubs" woke up all
of a sudden and played a fast game.
If the second half had been just ten
minutes longer the "Scrubs" would
have walked away with Dunhams.
Dunhams failed miserably at goal
several times.
Holliday, Iglehart and Fouke featured for Dunhams.
SCHMEISSER

ELECTED

The Lacrosse Team have finished
their mail balloting for a captain for
the coming season, and Gerhard L.
Schmeisser, '12, has been elected.
Schmeisser played goal on the team
last season, and should make an excellent leader for the team. He is
not only a strong player himself, but
he comes from a family that has lacrosse bred in its very bones. The
Schmeisser brothers hold a place in
Hopkins lacrosse that is comparable
to that held by the Poe family in football at Princeton. Our present lacrosse captain is the third of the family to hold this honorable position.
SOPHOMORE MEETING
The Sophomores held a meeting last
Tuesday and elected Max G. Paulus
the captain of their lacrosse team, and
J. K. Burg-an its manager. Captain
Schmeisser of the 'varsity lacrosse
team spoke and urged every member
of the class who is not out for football or track to come out for the lacrosse team this season.
The class voted to assess each of
its members to pay for the class banner, and T. Brooke Price, John S.
Fulton and G. H.Todes were appointed a committee to select the design
and order the flag.
